03_05.question: Which of the following statements about the 'new' operator in Java are true? (Select all that apply)

A.choice: It is used to create new objects.

B.choice: It is used to declare variables.

C.choice: It allocates memory for a new object.

D.choice: It is used to import classes from packages.

03_06.question: Which method would you use to get the length of a String called s?

03_07.question: Which of the following are true about the Math class in Java? (Select all that apply)

A.choice: It provides static methods for mathematical operations.

B.choice: You need to create a Math object to use its methods.

D.choice: Math.PI is a constant representing the value of pi.

03_09.question:
What is the value of x after the following code runs?

int x = (int) Math.floor(4.8);

03_10.question: Which of the following is true about String objects in Java?

B.choice: You can change the contents of a String after it is created.

D.choice: String objects can only be compared with '=='.

03_14.question: Which of the following statements best describes a wrapper class in Java?

A.choice: A class that wraps a primitive value in an object.

B.choice: A class used to handle exceptions.

D.choice: A class that manages the main memory.

A.choice: Automatic conversion of a primitive to its corresponding wrapper class.

C.choice: Converting a String to an int.

D.choice: Wrapping a class with another class.

03_16.question: Which of the following methods would you use to convert a String s = "10" to an int?

03_17.question: What does the term 'immutable' mean when referring to String objects?

A.choice: Their value cannot be changed once created.

B.choice: They can be modified using methods like append().

D.choice: They can only be compared using ==.

03_18.question: Which of the following will result in an error when working with String objects?

03_19.question: Which of the following statements about the equals() method for Strings is true?

A.choice: equals() compares the content of two Strings.

C.choice: equals() only works for int values.

D.choice: equals() is used to check if a String is null.

A.choice: true (because of integer caching for small values)

03_21.question: Which of the following statements about the Scanner class are correct? (Select all that apply)

A.choice: Scanner can read input from System.in.

B.choice: Scanner can parse input into different types like int or double.

C.choice: Scanner requires java.util to be imported.

D.choice: Scanner objects are created with 'Scanner sc = new Scanner();'

03_22.question: Which of the following best describes the relationship between a class and an object in Java?

A.choice: A class is a blueprint; an object is an instance of a class.

B.choice: An object defines the methods for a class.

C.choice: A class and an object are always the same.

D.choice: A class is a variable that stores data.

03_23.question: Which of the following correctly declares a reference variable for an object in Java?

03_24.question: Which of the following statements are true about object references in Java? (Select all that apply)

A.choice: Object references store the memory address of the object.

B.choice: Multiple variables can refer to the same object.

C.choice: You can copy an object reference to another variable.

D.choice: An object reference cannot be reassigned.

03_25.question: What happens if an object no longer has any valid references?

A.choice: It becomes eligible for garbage collection.

C.choice: It is stored in the stack memory.

03_26.question: Which method call correctly creates a random integer between 0 and 9 (inclusive) in Java?

03_27.question: Which of the following are methods of the Math class? (Select all that apply)

03_28.question: Which statement is true about the use of the '.' (dot) operator in Java?

A.choice: It is used to access fields and methods of an object.

B.choice: It is used to declare a new class.

C.choice: It is used to create an object.

D.choice: It is used to assign a value to a variable.

03_29.question:
Given Rectangle box = new Rectangle();
Which of the following is the correct way to call a method named 'setWidth' on the box object?

03_30.question: Which of the following is the purpose of a constructor in Java?

A.choice: To initialize a new object's state when it is created.

B.choice: To delete an object from memory.

C.choice: To run before the main method starts.

D.choice: To assign a value to a primitive variable.

03_36.question: Which of the following statements about wrapper classes is true?

A.choice: They provide a way to use primitive data types as objects.

B.choice: They are only available for int and double.

C.choice: They cannot be used in collections.

D.choice: They can change the value of primitives directly.

03_37.question: What does the equals() method do when comparing two String objects?

A.choice: Compares their actual contents for equality.

D.choice: Converts both Strings to lowercase first.

A.choice: Reading user input from the console.

D.choice: Parsing input into int or double types.

03_40.question: What will happen if you try to use a reference variable that does not point to any object?

C.choice: It will create a new object automatically.

B.choice: Converting a String to an object.

C.choice: Converting a primitive to a String.

D.choice: Wrapping an object inside another object.

03_46.question: What does the Scanner method nextInt() do?

A.choice: Reads the next int value from the input.

B.choice: Reads the next double value from the input.

C.choice: Reads the next token as a String.

D.choice: Reads the next line of text.

03_47.question: Which of the following best describes method overloading?

A.choice: Defining multiple methods with the same name but different parameter lists.

B.choice: Using multiple classes in one file.

C.choice: Calling a method from another class.

D.choice: Using a method inside a loop.

What does the following code print?

System.out.println("Java".substring(1, 3));

B.choice: They are stored directly in memory.

C.choice: They can be used as generic type arguments.

D.choice: They are automatically converted to objects.

03_56.question: What does the 'null' keyword represent in Java?

A.choice: A reference that points to no object.

B.choice: The default value for all primitive types.

C.choice: A value of 0 for int variables.

D.choice: A reference to the first object in memory.

03_57.question: Which of the following statements about object instantiation is true?

A.choice: The new operator allocates memory for the object.

B.choice: The constructor deletes old objects from memory.

C.choice: You must always use the new operator to call methods.

D.choice: Objects are stored on the stack, not the heap.

03_58.question: Which of the following statements are true about reference variables in Java? (Select all that apply)

A.choice: They store memory addresses, not actual objects.

B.choice: They can refer to objects of their declared type.

D.choice: They are used only for primitive types.

A.choice: To store primitive values in collections.

B.choice: To use methods for converting and parsing.

C.choice: To directly manipulate the value of primitives.

03_62.question: What will happen if you try to use a variable outside of its declared scope?

B.choice: The variable is automatically initialized to zero.

C.choice: The program ignores the variable and continues running.

D.choice: The variable will be set to null.

03_65.question: Why should you use named constants (final variables) in Java code?

A.choice: To make the code more readable and easier to maintain.

D.choice: Because constants are faster to execute than variables.
